historicalFigures.name: Simón Bolívar
historicalFigures.nativeName: Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios
historicalFigures.background: Simón Bolívar, known as 'El Libertador', was a Venezuelan military and political leader who led the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from the Spanish Empire.
keyDecisions: Swearing the Oath of Monte Sacro.
Crossing the Andes to liberate New Granada.
achievements: Greatest military figure of South America.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bolívar is the George Washington of South America. His dream of unity still inspires the continent.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Bolivia and Venezuela (Bolivarian Republic) are named after him.
modernInterpretations: His legacy is claimed by both left and right.

historicalFigures.name: Francisco de Miranda
historicalFigures.nativeName: Sebastián Francisco de Miranda y Rodríguez
historicalFigures.background: Francisco de Miranda was a military leader and revolutionary known as 'The Precursor'. He participated in the American Revolution, the French Revolution, and the Spanish American wars of independence.
keyDecisions: Fighting in the American Revolutionary War.
Serving as a General in the French Revolution.
Leading the first attempt to liberate Venezuela (1806).
achievements: The only man to fight in three major revolutions.
Designed the tricolor flag (Yellow, Blue, Red).
challenges: Betrayal (handed over to the Spanish by Bolívar).
historicalFigures.legacy: Miranda is the universal Venezuelan. His name is on the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
quotes: Tumult! Tumult! This is all I see.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the father of the flag.
modernInterpretations: His tragic end is a lesson in politics.

historicalFigures.name: Antonio José de Sucre
historicalFigures.nativeName: Antonio José de Sucre y Alcalá
historicalFigures.background: Antonio José de Sucre was a Venezuelan independence leader and the closest friend of Bolívar. He won the decisive Battle of Ayacucho, securing the independence of Peru.
keyDecisions: Leading the Patriot army at Pichincha.
Serving as the first President of Bolivia.
historicalFigures.legacy: Sucre is the 'Abel' of the revolution. He was the most talented and loyal of Bolívar's generals.
quotes: To win is not enough; one must know how to win.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The city of Sucre (Bolivia) and the currency (Ecuador) were named after him.
modernInterpretations: His murder is a historical tragedy.

historicalFigures.name: Rómulo Betancourt
historicalFigures.background: Rómulo Betancourt is known as the 'Father of Venezuelan Democracy'. He founded the Democratic Action party and established the Betancourt Doctrine (refusing to recognize dictatorships).
keyDecisions: Surviving an assassination attempt by Trujillo.
historicalFigures.legacy: Betancourt built the democratic institutions that lasted 40 years. He is a giant of 20th-century politics.
quotes: We will spend the oil to sow the oil.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He defined the modern Venezuelan state.
modernInterpretations: Criticized by the left for excluding communists.

historicalFigures.name: Hugo Chávez
historicalFigures.background: Hugo Chávez was a military officer and politician who served as President from 1999 until his death. He led the 'Bolivarian Revolution', focusing on socialism and anti-imperialism.
keyDecisions: Using oil wealth for social programs (Misiones).
historicalFigures.legacy: Chávez changed Venezuela forever. He is a messiah to his supporters and a dictator to his critics.
modernInterpretations: His economic legacy is a disaster, but his social impact is undeniable.

historicalFigures.name: Teresa Carreño
historicalFigures.nativeName: María Teresa Gertrudis de Jesús Carreño García
historicalFigures.background: Teresa Carreño was a pianist, singer, composer, and conductor. Known as the 'Valkyrie of the Piano', she was an international superstar.
keyDecisions: Performing for Abraham Lincoln at the White House (age 9).
Composing the Venezuelan anthem (unofficial) 'Himno a Bolívar'.
historicalFigures.legacy: Teresa Carreño is the greatest Venezuelan musician. The main theater in Caracas is named after her.
quotes: I am a citizen of the world.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a symbol of artistic excellence.
modernInterpretations: Her life is a feminist inspiration.

historicalFigures.name: Andrés Bello
historicalFigures.nativeName: Andrés de Jesús María y José Bello López
historicalFigures.background: Andrés Bello was a poet, lawmaker, philosopher, and educator. He was the teacher of Simón Bolívar and a major intellectual figure in Chile.
keyDecisions: Going to London as a diplomat.
Writing the Civil Code of Chile.
achievements: Founder of the University of Chile.
Author of the Grammar of the Spanish Language.
challenges: Being ignored by the Venezuelan government.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bello is the intellectual father of South America. His grammar book is still the reference.
quotes: The sciences and letters are the property of no one.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is on the currency of Venezuela and Chile.
primarySources: Silva a la agricultura de la zona tórrida.
modernInterpretations: His contribution to law and language is immense.

historicalFigures.name: Rómulo Gallegos
historicalFigures.background: Rómulo Gallegos was a novelist and politician. He wrote 'Doña Bárbara', a masterpiece of Latin American literature, and served as the first democratically elected president (briefly).
keyDecisions: Going into exile after the 1948 coup.
historicalFigures.legacy: Gallegos is the literary conscience of Venezuela. His conflict between 'civilization and barbarism' defines the nation.
modernInterpretations: His presidency is a symbol of lost hope.

historicalFigures.name: José Gregorio Hernández
historicalFigures.background: José Gregorio Hernández was a physician and researcher known for his charity and piety. He is beatified by the Catholic Church and revered as the 'Doctor of the Poor'.
keyDecisions: Attempting to become a monk (failed due to health).
Dying after being hit by one of the few cars in Caracas.
historicalFigures.legacy: José Gregorio is the spiritual doctor of Venezuela. Millions pray to him for healing.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His image is in every home.
modernInterpretations: His beatification was a national celebration.

historicalFigures.name: Carlos Cruz-Diez
historicalFigures.background: Carlos Cruz-Diez was a kinetic and op artist. He is considered one of the greatest color thinkers of the 20th century.
keyDecisions: Integrating art into architecture (Maiquetía Airport floor).
challenges: Watching his country's decline from afar.
historicalFigures.legacy: Cruz-Diez brought color to the world. His floor at the airport is the symbol of the Venezuelan diaspora.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a source of national pride.

historicalFigures.name: Carolina Herrera
historicalFigures.nativeName: María Carolina Josefina Pacanins y Niño (Carolina Herrera)
historicalFigures.background: Carolina Herrera is a fashion designer known for her elegance and style. She founded her eponymous brand and dressed First Ladies from Jacqueline Onassis to Michelle Obama.
keyDecisions: Launching her first collection at age 42.
Creating the white shirt as a staple.
historicalFigures.legacy: Carolina Herrera is the face of Venezuelan elegance. She proved that style has no age.
quotes: Elegance is the only beauty that never fades.
modernInterpretations: Symbol of the old Venezuelan aristocracy.

historicalFigures.name: Simón Rodríguez
historicalFigures.background: Simón Rodríguez was a philosopher and educator. He was the tutor and mentor of Simón Bolívar, influencing his republican ideas.
historicalFigures.legacy: Rodríguez is the 'Socrates of Caracas'. His call to 'invent or err' is a motto for Latin America.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Misión Robinson (literacy program) is named after him.
modernInterpretations: His ideas on education are still radical.

historicalFigures.name: Gustavo Dudamel
historicalFigures.background: Gustavo Dudamel is a conductor and violinist. A product of 'El Sistema', he is the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and a global star.
keyDecisions: Leading the Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra.
challenges: Criticism for not speaking out earlier.
historicalFigures.legacy: Dudamel is the proof of the power of music. He put Venezuelan classical music on the map.
quotes: Music is a fundamental human right.
modernInterpretations: His relationship with the regime was controversial.

historicalFigures.name: Luisa Cáceres de Arismendi
historicalFigures.background: Luisa Cáceres was a heroine of the War of Independence. She was imprisoned and tortured by the Spanish to pressure her husband, General Arismendi, to surrender.
keyDecisions: Enduring imprisonment in Santa Rosa castle.
historicalFigures.legacy: Luisa is the symbol of Venezuelan womanhood. Her courage is legendary.
quotes: I will never advise my husband to fail in his duty.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her face is on the currency.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a martyr of liberty.
Her story is taught in schools.

historicalFigures.name: Arturo Uslar Pietri
historicalFigures.background: Arturo Uslar Pietri was a writer, television producer, and politician. He coined the phrase 'sembrar el petróleo' (sow the oil).
historicalFigures.legacy: Uslar Pietri warned Venezuela about the oil curse. His warning went unheeded.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the grandfather of the nation.

historicalFigures.name: Miguel Cabrera
historicalFigures.background: Miguel Cabrera is a baseball player. He is one of the greatest hitters of all time, winning the Triple Crown in 2012.
keyDecisions: Winning the World Series as a rookie.
historicalFigures.legacy: Miggy is the greatest Venezuelan baseball player. He is a national idol.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Baseball is religion in Venezuela, and he is the pope.

historicalFigures.name: Jesús Soto
historicalFigures.background: Jesús Soto was a kinetic artist. He is famous for his 'Penetrables', interactive sculptures that viewers can walk through.
keyDecisions: Founding the Soto Museum in Ciudad Bolívar.
historicalFigures.legacy: Soto made art move. His museum is a jewel in the jungle.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His Sphere in Caracas is a landmark.
modernInterpretations: His work is playful and profound.

historicalFigures.name: Rafael Urdaneta
historicalFigures.background: Rafael Urdaneta was a general and the last President of Gran Colombia. He was known as 'The Loyal One' for his unwavering support of Bolívar.
keyDecisions: Assuming the presidency to save Bolívar's legacy.
historicalFigures.legacy: Urdaneta is the symbol of loyalty. He was the rock upon which Bolívar leaned.
quotes: General, if two men are enough to liberate the country, count on me.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Maracaibo's bridge is named after him.
